coredata.dc:title: A novel cross-linked nanocomposite solid-state electrolyte with super flexibility and performance for lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Tang, Shun
Lan, Qian
Xu, Lin
Liang, Jiyuan
Lou, Ping
Liu, Cui
Mai, Liqiang
Cao, Yuan-Cheng
Cheng, Shijie
coredata.dc:description: Solid-state electrolyte batteries are considered as one of the promising next generation power sources. A novel cross-linked nanocomposite polymer electrolyte (CNPE) based on poly (propylene oxide)-poly (ethylene oxide)-poly (propylene oxide) triblock main chains and surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticles are prepared to establish a super flexible and stable polymer framework. The CNPE exhibits high ionic conductivity of 1.32 mS cm−1 at 20 °C and its electrochemical stability window reaches up to 6.5 V (versus Li+/Li). The favorable Li deposition behavior provided by CNPE films is identified by the stripping/plating test at a current density of 2.4 mA cm−2 for 1700 h. The CNPE films possess excellent mechanical stability (highly stretchable with ultimate elongation of 700%). Li/CNPE/LiFePO4 batteries deliver an initial discharge capacity of 160 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, which is 94.1% of the theoretic capacity, and maintain the high specific capacity of 148 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C. This work provides a new approach toward designing high performance electrolyte for lithium metal batteries.

Nanocomposite
Lithium metal battery
Stretchable
Large electrochemical window

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic illustration of Preparation of CNPEs: (a) Synthesis route of CNPE500 and 1000. (b) Complementary hydrogen bonds among different polymer chains in CNPEs. (c) The typical image of CNPE film on the PTFE plate. (d) The typical image of sol-gel process of CNPE over a prolonged time. (e) Graphical representation of the 3D framework in CNPEs.

Characterization of TEM images of SiO2 nanoparticles before (a,b) and after (c,d) surface modification. (e) The schematic illustration of the transport paths of Li ion in the polymer segments and in the internal channels.

Excellent mechanical, thermal and electrochemical properties: (a) Stress-strain curves of CNPE500 and 1000 membranes. Images of CNPE1000 membrane before (b) and after (c) break. (d) Typical image of the large elongation of CNPE1000 before break. Thermograms of membranes and their PEO-NPs linkers for CNPE500 (e) and CNPE1000 (f). (g) Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy of CNPE500 and 1000 at room temperature. (h,i) CNPE500 at various temperature ranging from 10 °C to 60 °C. (j) Arrhenius plots of ionic conductivity versus inverse temperature of CNPE500 and CNPE1000.
Cyclic voltammograms of Li/CNPE/SS cells assembled by using CNPE500 (a,c) and CNPE1000 (b,d) for 5 cycles at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1. (e) Illustration of high electrochemical stability of CNPE.

Stripping/plating tests of a symmetric Li/CNPE500/Li cell with various current densities and capacities at room temperature: (a–d) 1.2 mA cm−2 and 1.2 mAh cm−2, (e–h) 1.2 mA cm−2 and 1.8 mAh cm−2, (i–l) 2.4 mA cm−2 and 3.6 mAh cm−2, and (m–p) 4.8 mA cm−2 and 1.2 mAh cm−2.

Initial charge-discharge curves of the LiFePO4/CNPE/Li batteries using CNPE500 (a) and CNPE1000 (b) at various C-rate between 2.5 V and 4.0 V. Discharge capacities of the LiFePO4/CNPE/Li batteries using CNPE500 (c) and CNPE1000 (d) in a series of charge-discharge cycles at various C-rate. Cycle performance of the LiFePO4/CNPE/Li batteries using CNPE500 (e) and CNPE1000 (f) at the rate of 0.5 C.

head.ce:title: A novel cross-linked nanocomposite solid-state electrolyte with super flexibility and performance for lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Solid-state electrolyte batteries are considered as one of the promising next generation power sources. A novel cross-linked nanocomposite polymer electrolyte (CNPE) based on poly (propylene oxide)-poly (ethylene oxide)-poly (propylene oxide) triblock main chains and surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticles are prepared to establish a super flexible and stable polymer framework. The CNPE exhibits high ionic conductivity of 1.32 mS cm−1 at 20 °C and its electrochemical stability window reaches up to 6.5 V (versus Li+/Li). The favorable Li deposition behavior provided by CNPE films is identified by the stripping/plating test at a current density of 2.4 mA cm−2 for 1700 h. The CNPE films possess excellent mechanical stability (highly stretchable with ultimate elongation of 700%). Li/CNPE/LiFePO4 batteries deliver an initial discharge capacity of 160 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, which is 94.1% of the theoretic capacity, and maintain the high specific capacity of 148 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C. This work provides a new approach toward designing high performance electrolyte for lithium metal batteries.

ce:section.ce:para: Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with carbon anode have been considered as one of the most important power sources for portable electronic devices, electric vehicles and grid-level energy storage systems [1–7]. The successful commercialization of LIBs depends on the wide application of carbon anode materials. Recently, a considerable number of studies has been conducted on the lithium-metal batteries (LMBs) in order to meet the developing demand of high energy density of next-generation lithium batteries, since Li metal itself is the desirable anode material with offering relatively lower density of 0.59 g cm−3, the lowest potential of −3.04 V versus standard hydrogen electrode and the highest specific capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 [8–17]. Nevertheless, there are still several well-known issues should be addressed for the practical application of LMBs, including the short circuit caused by uncontrolled Li dendrites [1,18–20], low Coulombic efficiency during cycling and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) generated from highly active Li metal. To date, in order to improve the cycling stability, numerous methods have been employed via modifying liquid electrolytes [21,22], generating an artificial SEI [23,24] and using a robust separator [14]. However, the safety issues associated with combustion and explosion remain due to the leakage of organic electrolytes. Another attractive strategy for enhanced safety is to employ solid ceramic electrolyte (SCE) or solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) membranes [25–48]. These strategies have proven to be efficient in inhibition of Li dendrites and suppression of solvent leakage thanks to satisfied mechanical integrity of membranes. Despite the numerous advantages, the application of these membranes is severely limited. For instance, the rigid structure of SCEs results in large interfacial resistance and poor contact at the electrolyte/electrode interface, while SPEs exhibit insufficient ionic conductivity. In recent years, researchers have pursued several approaches for improving the ionic conductivity, interfacial compatibility and mechanical property of SPE by establishing cross-linked polymer framework or introducing nanoparticle fillers into flexible polymer matrix [49–54]. However, how to make the balance between the electrochemical performance and the long-term stability (chemical and mechanical robustness) in the development of solid electrolytes remains a great challenge for practical application of LMBs.

In this work, we propose a novel method to prepare cross-linked nanocomposite polymer electrolytes (CNPEs) based on poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO) and poly (propylene oxide) (PPO) oligomers. First, hydrophobic-hydrophilic-hydrophobic triblock copolymers (PPO-PEO-PPO) was synthesized by using toluene-2, 4-diisocyanate (TDI) as linkages. Then the CNPEs containing enhanced framework were generated form the copolymers and surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticles, which led to effective solvation of lithium salts and encapsulation of organic solvents. The CNPE membranes exhibited a high ionic conductivity at ambient temperature, extended electrochemical stability window and excellent mechanical property as designed. In addition, LMBs with CNPE provided superior performance with long cycle life and good rate capability.

Dihydroxyl terminated PEO (Mw = 500, 1000 g mol−1) and Dihydroxyl terminated PPO (Mw = 2000 g mol−1) were purchased from Fuzhou YoTe Pharmaceutical Technology. These polymers were dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 24 h prior to use. 3-Isocyanatopropyl triethoxysilane (IPTS, 95%) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology. Toluene-2, 4-diisocyanate (TDI 100, tech. 98%, remainder Toluene-2, 6-diisocyanate) was supplied by Fosai New Material. Dibutyltin dilaurate (DBTDL, 95%) was obtained from TCI (Shanghai). Development Co., Ltd. Ludox SM30 colloidal silica was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99%), hexane (97%), chloroform (99%) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. All solvents were dried and distilled under argon. Lithium hexafluorophosphate solution (1 M LiPF6) in ethyl carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and Lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide solution (1 M LiTFSI) in propylene carbonate (PC) were received from DodoChem and stored in a glovebox for further use. The lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiFePO4), N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP), and polyvinyldifluoride (PVDF) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Carbon black and graphite were purchased from Alfa Aesar.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticle cross-linkers
ce:section.ce:para: Dihydroxyl terminated PEO500 (HO-PEO-OH, Mw = 500 g mol−1, 10.0 g, 20 mmol) was dissolved in 100 mL THF in a three-necked flask. Then DBTDL (5 mol%) was added to the mixture while the system was kept under an argon atmosphere. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 60 °C for 12 h. After completion of the reaction, the crude mixture was concentrated and followed by addition of hexane (200 mL). A white precipitate was instantly formed. The precipitate was filtered off and washed by hexane. The resulting solid was dried under vacuum for 24 h to afford triethoxysilane-terminated PEO (HO-PEO500-TES). Afterward, Ludox SM30 colloidal silica (1.6 mL) and HO-PEO500-TES was mixed in water (20 mL), and magnetically stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. After completion of the hydrolysis, the obtained mixture was dissolved in THF, and then concentrated. The crude product was centrifuged in hexane and chloroform respectively, for three times at a speed of 16,000 r.p.m for 25 min. A white solid was isolated by filtration and dried under high vacuum for 48 h to afford the desired surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticle clusters (HO-PEO500-NPCs). HO-PEO1000-NPCs was prepared via similar procedure by using PEO1000 (HO-PEO-OH, Mw = 1000 g mol−1) instead of PEO500.

TDI (3.48 g, 20 mmol) was dissolved in 100 mL chloroform in a three-necked flask. Then DBTDL (5 mol%) was added as the catalyst to the mixture while the system was kept under an argon atmosphere. PPO2000 (HO-PPO-OH, Mw = 2000 g mol−1, 20.0 g, 10 mmol) was dissolved in 50 mL chloroform and added dropwise into the flask by a micro syringe pump at ambient temperature and the reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 60 °C for 3 h. Then, PEO500 (0.5 g, 1 mmol) dissolved in 50 mL chloroform was added dropwise and the reaction mixture was stirred for another 1 h at the same temperature. Afterward, HO-PEO500-NPCs (2 g) was added to crosslink the triblock PPO-PEO-PPO copolymers, and the reaction mixture time was prolonger for 3 h at 60 °C. Then the crude mixture was concentrated to afford a viscous liquid, which was poured on polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) plate under an argon atmosphere. Finally, the CNPE500 membrane was obtained after solvent evaporation at ambient temperature for 48 h under vacuum with an average thickness of 150 μm (a prolonged time may be necessary for the generation of membranes). Similarly, the CNPE1000 membrane was prepared by using PEO1000 instead of PEO500. The CNPE membranes were soaked in 1 M LiPF6 (EC/DMC, v/v = 1/1) liquid electrolyte solution for 3 min at ambient temperature in a glove box, in order to restrict the liquid electrolyte content to a maximum of 200% weight of original membranes (the CNPE uptake behavior is presented in Supplementary Fig. S1).

The structure of precursors was characterized by Proton Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (1H NMR) spectrometry with a RDX 400 MHz Bruker spectrometer. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG 209 F3 Netzsch) was carried out to measure the composite electrolyte from 0 to 600 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. The films were analyzed by the mechanical property tester (SANS CMT6503, China) with the speed of 5 mm min−1. The microstructure properties of polymer electrolytes were characterized by a high-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (Tecnai G2F20). The electrolyte uptake was determined by measuring the weight increase of the CNPE500 membrane which was soaked in a liquid electrolyte (1.0 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC), and calculated by using the following the equation

The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement were characterized by using AutoLab (PGDTAT302 N) under the open circuit potential (OCP), and the frequency is 10−3-105 Hz using symmetric Li/CNPE/Li cell. For studying the lithium ion transfer number (tLi +) of CNPE500, a combination measurement of polarization chronoamperometry and EIS was performed. A polarization voltage of 10 mV was applied to the cell for 10000 s, and tLi + was calculated from Bruce-Vincent-Evans equation

where ΔV is the applied polarization voltage, I0 and Iss represent the initial and steady-state currents, and R0 and Rss represent the initial and steady-state interfacial resistance, respectively. The electrochemical stability of the composite electrolytes were based on cyclic voltammetry (CV) scans, using AutoLab (PGDTAT302 N) with a voltage range from −1.0 to 7.0 V at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 and potentiostatic signal amplitude of 10 mV using Li/CNPE/stainless steel (SS) cell (CNPE membranes were soaked in 1 M LiTFSI-PC for 2 h). The charge-discharge tests were measured by LFP/electrolytes/Li at the cut-off voltage range from 2.5 V to 4.0 V using LAND Electronics. The Rate and cyclic performance is the decisive factor of the polymer electrolyte's stability. The films were sandwiched between lithium anode and LiFePO4 cathode. The LiFePO4 cathode was made of the active materials with acetylene black and PVDF in the weight ratio of 8:1:1. The active material mass loading was controlled to be 1.5–1.9 mg cm−2. The strip-plate tests at various current densities and areal capacities (1.2–4.8 mA cm−2, 1.2–3.6 mAh cm−2, respectively) were characterized by symmetric Li/CNPE/Li cell. All of the different assemble cells were organized under argon environment in a glove box.

The overall synthetic pathway of CNPEs is outlined in Fig. 1 a–d. In the first step, PPO-PEO-PPO triblock precursors were generated via the stepwise addition reactions of TDI with PEO and PPO oligomers. The isocyanate groups (-NCO) in TDI were reacted with the terminal hydroxyl groups (-OH) of the polyether polyols in the presence of dibutyltin dilaurate (DBTDL) as a catalyst. Then 3-Isocyanatopropyl triethoxysilane (IPTS) was chemically attached with PEO oligomer chain, which was followed by the hydrolysis of the triethoxysilane end groups with colloidal SiO2 nanoparticles in water to afford the surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticle clusters as cross-linkable sites. The formation of urethane links in HO-PEO-TES was confirmed by 1H NMR spectra (Supplementary Fig. S2). In the final step, the CNPE was successfully synthesized via sol-gel method by mixing the triblock polymer precursors and SiO2 nanoparticle clusters in organic solvent to establish a 3-dimensional (3D) framework. This reaction should be carefully monitored because of its rapid and irreversible polymerization (Fig. 1d).

General speaking, the matrix structure of CNPE contains the ether groups (-O-), duplicated aromatic urethane groups (-O-CO-NH-Ar-NH-CO-O-) and the SiO2 nanoparticle clusters, which provide its diversity of functionality and micro-phase separation of polymer segments like polyurethane. On one hand, the introduction of SiO2 nanoparticle clusters increased the cross-linkable nodes of the CNPE and reduced the crystallization of PEO chains. Thus more amorphous phase in the PEO and PPO chains could provide more Li-ion transport pathways. On the other hand, the polar hard segments (urethane groups) offered complementary hydrogen bonding system and the rigid aromatic groups in CNPEs, while the nonpolar soft segments (PEO and PPO chains) offered the flexible and mobile linkages (Fig. 1b). The micro-phase separation of the hard and soft segments occurred in CNPEs because of their poor miscibility and compatibility. If the two types of segments were simply mixed together, their incompatibility could result in macro-phase separation. However, the hard and soft segments were covalently linked and they underwent self-assembled aggregation to form the hard and soft domain respectively, without any macroscopic phase separation. In particular, the strong complementary hydrogen bonding in urethane groups is considered to be the driving force for the micro-phase separation [55]. The formation of multiple hydrogen bonds led to self-complementarity of different copolymerized chains between two SiO2 nanoparticle clusters, so that the PEO and PPO segments were twisted together in a tangled mass. Upon external tensile stress, the soft segments in rubbery state uncoiled, while the hard segments became aligned in the stress direction (Fig. 1e). In a word, it is reasonable to believe that the two-phase microstructure plays an important role in inhibiting the PEO crystallization and creating elastomeric resiliency and enhanced elongation.

For further investigation, the morphologies of colloidal silica and surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticles were characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). It is clearly illustrated in Fig. 2 a–b that high monodispersity of SiO2 nanoparticles was observed as well-distributed nanospheres (D ≈ 10 nm). After surface modification of SiO2 nanoparticles by hydrolysis of HO-PEO-TES in water, a protecting layer was generated around each SiO2 nanosphere, which was indicated by the darker-colored coating in Fig. 2c–d. However, only an irregularly shaped aggregate of SiO2 nanoparticles was observed instead of a perfect spherical cluster. The degradation of clusters could be attributed to strong mechanical forces during centrifugation processes. The subsurface materials exhibited a cross-linked 3D framework containing numerous mesoscale pores and internal pore channels. This structure is supposed to be beneficial for the efficient uptake and effective encapsulation of the electrolyte solution during the swelling process, and also promoting Li ionic conductivity by creating 3D ion transport paths (Fig. 2e). As far as mechanism of lithium-ion conduction is concerned, it is appropriate to consider the CNPE as a semi-solid electrolyte containing two types of lithium-ion transport pathways. In the polymer segments, lithium-ions could transfer between the polymer chains via coordination/dissociation of lithium-ions with the ether oxygen. In addition, the lithium-ions could also transfer from one polymer segment to another in inner porous channels of CNPE framework via lithium ion diffusion in the liquid electrolyte.

The good mechanical properties are essential for electrolyte films to prevent the potential interfacial short-circuit in LMBs and to improve the safety. Tensile tests were carried out for CNPE500 and CNPE1000 membranes, and the results are displayed in Fig. 3 a. CNPE500 membrane exhibited a breaking tensile strength of 0.026 MPa and its elongation at break reached up to 390%. However, the break strength and ultimate elongation of CNPE1000 were observed to be 0.05 MPa and 700%, respectively. The significant improvement of modulus and elongation to break could be attributed to the increase of molecular weight of soft segments. In addition, both the test samples exhibited small permanent deformation after break, which suggested the high resiliency and elasticity of materials (Fig. 3b–d). As expected, the CNPE membrane possessed a rubbery mechanical sate with high tensile strain, which is beneficial in the application of flexible LMBs.

The thermal degradation of CNPEs and their corresponding linkers was studied by TGA under a nitrogen atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 3e–f, the decomposition of all the samples followed a similar pattern in thermograms. Both the membranes start losing weight at about 290 °C with a drastic fall in weight thereafter. CNPE500 had 3.56% residual mass at 400 °C, while CNPE1000 had 2.55% residual mass at 400 °C. Furthermore, the silica linkers began to lose weight at about 350 °C. At 400 °C, PEO500-NPs had 26.21% weight left, while PEO1000-NPs had 23.80% weight left. The residual weight of the sample was equivalent to the weight of the remaining SiO2 additive in the materials after the degradation of polymers. The TGA results indicate that the CNPEs possess satisfied thermal stability for considering as electrolytes in LMBs.

The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was utilized to analyze the ionic conductivity of the CNPEs and cells with symmetric configuration of lithium (Li/CNPE/Li) were assembled and aged for 24 h at 40 °C. The CNPE membranes were soaked in the corresponding liquid electrolytes for 3 min during the course of assembling batteries, in order to restrict the liquid electrolyte content to a maximum of 200% weight of original membranes (uptake amount < 200%). The prolonged time of swelling in the electrolyte solution and the high uptake percentage of liquid electrolyte could definitely deteriorate the mechanical properties and interfacial compatibility of CNPE membranes. Fig. 3g shows the spectra of CNPE500 and CNPE1000 at room temperature, in which two semicircles were observed for each sample. The first one observed in the medium-to-high frequency corresponds to the interfacial resistance between the CNPE membrane and electrodes (Rf). The second semicircle appearing in the low frequency is due to the charge transfer resistance (Rct). And the bulk resistance (Re) of CNPEs is the intercept at the real axis. The equivalent circuit in Fig. 3g is used to fit the two semicircles. Thus, the result suggests that the interfacial resistance of CNPE1000 is much higher than that of CNPE500, which is likely due to the poor stability or interfacial contact of SEI film formed in the cell of CNPE1000. The EIS results of CNPE500 at various temperature ranging from 10 °C to 60 °C is displayed in Fig. 3h–i. The ionic conductivity of CNPE500 was calculated to be 1.32 mS cm−1 at 20 °C and 2.40 mS cm−1 at 60 °C, which is comparable to the liquid electrolytes. The typical Arrhenius plots of ionic conductivity versus inverse temperature (1000/T) is illustrated in Fig. 3j, which implies that the conductive environment of Li+ in the CNPE500 is liquid-like and thermally sensitive. However, the ionic conductivity of CNPE1000 was lower by more than an order of magnitude at 20 °C. According to the TGA tests, both of PEO500-NPs and PEO1000-NPs had about 25% weight of remaining of SiO2 left at 400 °C. These interesting results indicate that the number of PEO500 chains bonded on the surface of PEO500-NPs was twice as many as that of PEO1000 on PEO1000-NPs, since both of nanoparticles had roughly the same polymer content. Thus, the PEO500-NPs provided more structural complexity for the generation of cross-linked 3D framework in CNPE500, which lead to more efficient uptake and encapsulation of electrolyte solution. Accordingly, the CNPE500 exhibited a better performance in electrochemical tests than CNPE1000, since the CNPE1000 films could not soak up enough electrolyte solution as CNPE500 within the same swelling time. Considering two types of lithium-ion transport pathways inside CNPE membranes, the polymer coordinating mechanism could play a more important role in CNPE1000 at low temperature. At 60 °C, CNPE1000 exhibited similar ionic conductivity as CNPE500 did.

The lithium ion transference number (tLi +) is another critical factor to evaluate the electrochemical performance of CNPEs. Low tLi + can result in concentration gradients in the electrolytes, which will limit active material utilization and lead to low energy density and lifetime of batteries via concentration polarization. In order to study tLi + of CNPE500, a combination measurement of polarization chronoamperometry and EIS was performed. The calculated tLi + of CNPE500 is approximately 0.44 (Supplementary Fig. S3), which is slightly higher than tLi + of most of liquid electrolytes (from 0.1 to 0.4) [56]. The relatively high tLi + is beneficial for reducing concentration polarization and has a positive effect on the performance of cells assembled with CNPE500.

The electrochemical stability of CNPEs was investigated by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments of Li/CNPE/stainless steel (SS) cells under a scanning range from −1.0 to 7.0 V at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 4 a–d, the significant cathodic peaks observed at about −0.5 V correspond to the plating of Li+ ion onto the SS electrode, while the anodic peaks at around 0.4 V indicate the stripping of lithium. The CNPE500 exhibited a large stability window of at least 6.5 V versus Li+/Li, whereas the CNPE1000 produced an anodic stability range up to 6 V versus Li+/Li after 5 cycles of sweeping, in agreement with previous report [57]. The enhanced electrochemical stability of CNPEs could be attributed to the improved stability of polymer chains and the stable spontaneously-formed SEI in the liquid electrolyte. Theoretically, the polyether groups could be more stable against electrochemical oxidation, because of the adjacent electro-withdrawing urethane group and the grafted silica nanoparticles, as shown in Fig. 4e.

In order to evaluate stability and reversibility of lithium electrodeposition on the surface of Li metal anode during the long-term cycling, a series of lithium stripping/plating tests was carried out in symmetric Li/CNPE500/Li cells. As shown in Fig. 5 , the charging/discharging experiments were performed at various current densities and areal capacities. When the current density and capacity were fixed at 1.2 mA cm−2 and 1.2 mAh cm−2, respectively, the cell with CNPE500 exhibited highly-stable voltage profiles with ultra-flat over-potential of 80 mV during the whole lifespan of more than 1300 h (Fig. 5a–d). A controlled experiment was consequently performed under the same current density of 1.2 mA cm−2, but with a higher capacity of 1.8 mAh cm−2. It took about 2000 h to reach the same final cycle (670th cycle) as the first test without cell failure (Fig. 5e). The controlled cell show a lower over-potential of 60 mV after the initial cycles, and finally reached 180 mV. The incremental polarization voltage represents the continuously increased interfacial resistance, which is probably generated by accumulated dead lithium and thickened SEI layer. When the current density and capacity were promoted to 2.4 mA cm−2 and 3.6 mAh cm−2, respectively, the symmetric cell with CNPE500 displayed relatively stable voltage profiles and satisfied lifespan of 1700 h (Fig. 5i–l). Even at a higher current density of 4.8 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5m), the cell was capable of maintaining an acceptable cycling stability for 120 h (240 cycles) until the rapidly rise in over-potential (up to 3000 mV after 140 h). In order to guarantee the reproducibility and reliability of these results, more additional stripping/plating tests have been replicated at various current density (Supplementary Fig. S4). These cells exhibited highly-stable voltage profiles in their lifespans (600–1100 h) once again. Based on all the results, the surface morphology and the spontaneously generated oxide layer of lithium anode should be of critical importance in stripping/plating polarization. On one hand, the relatively unsteady voltage profiles in Fig. 5e should be ascribed to the occasional flaws and cracks on the surface of lithium anode, which could result in non-uniform deposition of lithium or the growth of lithium dendrites during the initial plating. On the other, the spontaneously generated oxide layer on the surface of lithium anode could accelerate the accumulation of dead lithium. The upward-sloping voltage plateaus implied that the conversion of extra lithium formed the anode to make up for dead lithium (Fig. 5f–h). The increased and uneven voltage profiles were the macroscopic expression of the accumulation of these negative effects, especially in a quite long time (>2000 h). Additionally, some voids were probably generated during the stripping/plating cycles leading to non-uniform deposition or dead lithium [58]. Compared with the cell in Fig. 5a, the areal capacity of the cell in Fig. 5e was increased to 1.8 mAh cm−2. The higher areal capacity could lead to the thicker lithium deposition layer for each cycle, which amplified these negative effects induced by the void formation in initial cycles. As a result, the rough surface of lithium anode with trace impurities (Li2O, LiOH, etc.) of the cell in Fig. 5e accumulated dead lithium and accelerated the void formation on the anode surface, which result in the increasing voltage plateaus. In summary, the stripping/plating results indicate that CNPE500 has proved to be effective in inhibition of Li dendrites and optimization of Li deposition at appropriate current densities and areal capacities. Although the generation rate of the spontaneously-formed SEI and dead lithium could play an important role in the performance of stripping/plating cycling[59], CNPE500 is robust enough to minimize the detrimental effects of them to extend lifespans of cells.

According to the results of CV and stripping/plating tests, the CNPEs were compatible for assembling LMBs with the configuration of LiFeO4/CNPE/Li in order to evaluate their rate performance and cyclic stability. Fig. 6 a–b displays initial charge-discharge profiles of LiFeO4/CNPE/Li, which were obtained by performing the cycling between 2.5 V and 4.0 V with different rates at room temperature. When running under 0.2 C (1 C = 170 mA g−1, based on the weight of LiFePO4), the CNPE500 based battery delivered an initial discharge capacity of 160 mAh g−1, which is 94.1% of theoretical capacity, while the CNPE1000 based battery delivered a lower initial discharge capacity of 145 mAh g−1. In addition, both batteries exhibited a charge plateau at 3.45 V and a discharge plateau at 3.35 V versus Li+/Li, which represented the typical mechanism of lithium extraction and insertion in the LiFeO4 cathode. However, distinct deviation of the voltage plateau from 3.4 V was observed as the rates increased for both CNPE based batteries, which could be attributed to polarization effect. Fig. 6c–d exhibits the battery discharge capacities operating in a series of galvanostatic charge-discharge cycles at diverse current densities form 0.2 C–2 C. The CNPE500 battery provided better performance than the CNPE1000 battery with a higher discharge capacity at each rate. In particular, the CNPE500 battery produced a high specific capacity of 160 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C. Even at a high rate of 2 C, satisfied specific capacity of 80 mAh g−1 could be attained. Moreover, both of the CNPE-based batteries demonstrated promising capacity reversibility without any decay when the rate decreased from 2 C to 0.5 C after 20 cycles. Additionally, the CNPE-based batteries could afford a good cycle performance with a negligible capacity loss after 100 cycles at the rate of 0.5 C. The CNPE500 battery exhibited the outstanding capacity retention of 148 mAh g−1, while the CNPE1000 battery maintained a relatively lower capacity of 136 mAh g−1. The Coulombic efficiency remained above 99% throughout the cycling process for each battery (Fig. 6e–f). These CNPEs possessed superior performance to other polymer electrolytes based on various polymers reported in the recent literatures (Supplementary Table S1) with regard to the cell capacity, cycling life, electrochemical stability and mechanical property. Hence, the remarkable rate performance and cyclic stability of LiFeO4/CNPE/Li batteries indicates the suitability of CNPEs for LMBs application, which is mainly due to the high ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability and good interfacial compatibility of CNPEs with lithium metal anode.

In summary, an approach towards synthesis of novel CNPEs based on PEO and PPO oligomers have been developed. By in situ introducing urethane groups and surface-modified SiO2 nanoparticles as cross-linkers, an enhanced framework of polymers has been established which led to effective solvation of lithium salts and encapsulation of organic solvents in the cell. It has been demonstrated that the CNPE membranes possessed high ionic conductivity, outstanding mechanical property, remarkable thermal stability, large electrochemical window and good interfacial compatibility to electrodes, benefiting from the unique microstructure of CNPEs. The LiFePO4/CNPE/Li batteries exhibited outstanding performance with long cycle life and good rate capability. In particular, outstanding specific capacity retention has been demonstrated. Furthermore, easily available raw materials, mild reaction conditions, short synthetic route for preparation of CNPEs offer the possibility for their practically industrialized production. Thus, the CNPEs are believed to have the potential in the application of LMBs.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Shun Tang received his B.Sc. degree from Wuhan University (Wuhan, China) in 2008. He received his Ph.D. in Organic Chemistry at Paris-Sud University (University of Paris XI, Paris, France) under the supervision of Prof. Vincent Gandon in 2014. He is currently a postdoctoral research fellow in Huazhong University of Science and Technology. His research interests focus on developing functional materials for solid-state lithium batteries.

Qian Lan received her M.S. degree in Polymer Materials and Engineering from Jianghan University (Wuhan, China) in 2012. She is currently working toward the B.S. degree and her research interests focus on synthesis of electrolyte materials for high energy storage devices.

Lin Xu received his Ph.D. degree in 2013 from School of Materials Science and Engineering at Wuhan University of Technology under the supervision of Professor Liqiang Mai, Professor Qingjie Zhang and Professor Charles M. Lieber. He was a visiting graduate student (2011–2013) and postdoctoral research fellow (2013–2016) in Lieber Research Group at Harvard University. He is currently a professor at State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing, Wuhan University of Technology. His research focuses on solid-state batteries.

Jiyuan Liang received his Ph.D degree in Chemistry from Nanjing University (Nanjing, China) in 2014, followed by a postdoctoral fellowship in chemical engineering at National Tsinghua University(Hsinchu, Taiwan) in 2015. He was appointed an associate professor at Jianghan University in August of 2016. His current research interests focus on nano chemistry, carbon materials, and energy conversion and storage.

Ping Lou received his Bachelor's degree from Xi'an Jiaotong University in 1988 and Master's degree from North China Electric Power University in 2007, respectively, all in Electrical Engineering. He joined State Grid Huzhou Power Supply Company in 1991. He is currently a senior engineer (professor) at State Grid Huzhou Power Supply Company and his research interests focus on distribution network integrated energy storage system.

Cui Liu received her Bachelor's degree in 2008 from Nankai University (Tianjin, China) and was awarded her Doctor's degree in 2013 from Wuhan University (Wuhan, China), and then she was appointed as lecture in 2013 at Jianghan University (Wuhan, China). Her current research interest includes the studies in molecular design, synthesis of materials for energy storage devices.

Liqiang Mai is Chang Jiang Scholar Professor and Chair Professor of Materials Science and Engineering at Wuhan University of Technology (WUT). He received his Ph.D. degree from WUT in 2004. He carried out his postdoctoral research in Prof. Zhonglin Wang's group at Georgia Institute of Technology in 2006–2007. He worked as advanced research scholar in the laboratory of Prof. Charles M. Lieber at Harvard University in 2008–2011 and the laboratory of Prof. Peidong Yang at University of California, Berkeley in 2017. His current research interests focus on new nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage and micro/nano energy devices.

Yuan-Cheng Cao is currently a professor of State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology at Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST). He received his Ph.D. from HUST in 2006. Then he worked in Nottingham Trent University (UK) in 2007–2010, before worked in Newcastle University (UK), all in the field of advanced materials for energy storage. He was selected as the member of “Hundred Talents Program” (2018), “Chutian Scholar” (2014) and “Yellow-Crane Talent” (2015). His research fields include solid state Li batteries for energy storage, recycling and regeneration of decommissioned batteries from EV.

Shijie Cheng received his Bachelor's degree from Xi'an Jiaotong University in 1967, his Master's degree from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 1981, and his Ph.D. from the University of Calgary, Canada in 1986, respectively, all in Electrical Engineering. In 2007, Prof. Cheng was elected the member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. He is currently a professor at HUST and engaged in the research on energy storage systems for electric power system stability and advanced materials for electrical engineering.
